item.title: What It Means to be a Writer
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1525" align="alignright" width="300" caption="JohnONolan on Flicker"][/caption]

Since I was a little boy, I've wanted to be a writer. Back then, that meant I got to spend all day writing stories, which was something I loved doing. I couldn't imagine a better way to spend my time than telling stories about dragons and spaceships. Since that's what writers did, I wanted to be a writer.

item.title: Book Review: The Art of Non-Conformity
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1385" align="alignright" width="118" caption="Clicking this image will take you to Amazon.com"][/caption]

Why jump off the bridge just because everyone else is doing it? You can step back from the bridge, turn around, and walk away into new adventures that had previously been only fleeting ideas. You can also help other people walk away from the bridge, or you can rewrite the rules the brought to the bridge in the first place. The possibilities are unlimited, but it all begins with the deliberate decision to think differently - Chris Guillebeau., The Art of Non-Conformity

It's been a while since I did a book review, as I've been reading several books at once. Nevertheless, I've finally managed to finish one, by fellow blogger and inspiration Chris Guillebeau of The Art of Non-Conformity. Chris is a self-described traveler and writer. He pays the bills by writing (which he can do from anywhere), and spends as much time as possible travelling the world with the ultimate goal of visiting every country. His book, The Art of Non-Conformity, provides readers with a glimpse of his unorthodox worldviews which, he maintains, are much more empowering and liberating than the traditional worldview we are taught to follow.

item.title: Freedom-Promoting Jobs
item.description:
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="400" caption="Candlemaker on Flickr"][/caption]

This is a repost of an article I wrote for another blog on career advice for young people.

“You just have to do your own thing, no matter what anyone says. It's your life.” - Ethan Embry

There are plenty of reasons out there why you would want to avoid a job like the plague. After all, there is a reason Robert Kiyosaki, author of Rich Dad, Poor Dad, refers to the dreaded word as a mere acronym for Just Over Broke. Nevertheless, getting a job is the easiest way there is to make money, if not necessarily the most desirable, and as such is an invaluable method for providing the necessary foundation to jump off to freedom. Let’s be ridiculous and say we want a job with few hours, lots of freedom, and plenty of money. Where on earth do you find one like that? Before we go on, let me define what exactly I mean when I say Job.
